I’m also encountering the same issue.  The clock offset seems to shift every time I relaunch Ignition Gazebo as well.  There seem to be different clocks published on /clock and sensor publishers have been confirmed to be referencing both separate clock times on the /clock topic.

‌

There seem to be a number of publishers on the ignition clock topic as well, this may be normal but it is something to look into:

content.raw:
A couple of extra clock publishers:

* The `ros1_ign` bridge is bidirectional, so it creates a clock publisher from ROS back to Ign. I don't think anything is publishing clock in the ROS side though.
* Enabling log record seems to add another clock publisher (i.e. `ign gazebo --record` , then check `ign topic -i -t /world/default/clock`). I'm looking into this.
content.html:
A couple of extra clock publishers:

  • The ros1_ign bridge is bidirectional, so it creates a clock publisher from ROS back to Ign. I don't think anything is publishing clock in the ROS side though.
  • Enabling log record seems to add another clock publisher (i.e. ign gazebo --record , then check ign topic -i -t /world/default/clock). I'm looking into this.

content.raw: @{5b90221dfa38ae2c89609691} @{557058:6ff86fcb-b7ab-44a5-b8a6-f6d9cae8b6e8} updating to ignition-gazebo2 version `2.2.0~pre1-1~bionic` resolves the clock issue I was having.  There may be more \(such as the ones you just identified\).
content.html: @Jon Fink @Louise Poubel updating to ignition-gazebo2 version 2.2.0~pre1-1~bionic resolves the clock issue I was having. There may be more (such as the ones you just identified).

content.raw: Glad to hear, @{557058:14b7fd50-d65a-47a8-825c-fa89681d07bd} . In any case, I found that the log recording is [republishing the clock topic](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/src/aeb86d615f4b50f2a2e09ec3e08c52ac1a9c5b09/src/Clock.cc#lines-76), and that may introduce interleaved delays. I think we may be using that wrong. Still looking into it.
content.html: Glad to hear, @Arthur Schang . In any case, I found that the log recording is republishing the clock topic, and that may introduce interleaved delays. I think we may be using that wrong. Still looking into it.

content.raw:
Alright, I updated the subt/Dockerfile to pull in the gazebo-latest when I update apt, which means it uses the prerelease version like Jon had above.

At first it seemed fixed, but I left the simulator running for like an hour and came back and it was happening. Now it is happening regularly, even if I close out and remove the docker image and restart it. Even more strange, I actually am getting robots appearing when I launch the virtual\_stix.ign file, even though apparently this should not be happening according to another thread. However, usually the robots don’t all appear for a while. After I came back to the simulator sitting for an hour, all four robot types \(X1-X4\) were all sitting in the staging area, though the X2 had floating parts.

It sort of seems like all four robots are trying to spawn, but they are on different clocks or something, and when the clocks actually catch up to each other, then the robot actually comes into the sim.
content.html:
Alright, I updated the subt/Dockerfile to pull in the gazebo-latest when I update apt, which means it uses the prerelease version like Jon had above.

At first it seemed fixed, but I left the simulator running for like an hour and came back and it was happening. Now it is happening regularly, even if I close out and remove the docker image and restart it. Even more strange, I actually am getting robots appearing when I launch the virtual_stix.ign file, even though apparently this should not be happening according to another thread. However, usually the robots don’t all appear for a while. After I came back to the simulator sitting for an hour, all four robot types (X1-X4) were all sitting in the staging area, though the X2 had floating parts.

It sort of seems like all four robots are trying to spawn, but they are on different clocks or something, and when the clocks actually catch up to each other, then the robot actually comes into the sim.

content.raw:
I’m not entirely sure what the pathology would be here, but I did notice that I can run two ignition instances in different docker containers and they will interact with each other \(no doubt because of net=host\). There is a chance that all of our ignition instances were interacting with each other over our internal network.

Maybe the service discovery mechanisms are really eager…
content.html:
I’m not entirely sure what the pathology would be here, but I did notice that I can run two ignition instances in different docker containers and they will interact with each other (no doubt because of net=host). There is a chance that all of our ignition instances were interacting with each other over our internal network.

Maybe the service discovery mechanisms are really eager…

content.raw:
You can do a quick experiment and set the environment variable `IGN_PARTITION` to something unique inside your Docker container. E.g.:

```
export IGN_PARTITION=testing_ethan_1
```

And then, try it running the simulation again.
content.html:
You can do a quick experiment and set the environment variable IGN_PARTITION to something unique inside your Docker container. E.g.:

export IGN_PARTITION=testing_ethan_1

And then, try it running the simulation again.

content.raw:
Setting the `IGN_PARTITION` on my two running containers to be different did not seem to fix the issue \(I used `IGN_PARTITION=subt$(date +%s%N)` in the Dockerfile\)

As a side note: if ignition is running in the docker container, I can interact with it from the host if I set the `IGN_PARTITION=subt` variable\\

Also: this solves our other mystery of why we got robots even though robot names were not specified on the command line \(see e.g. issue #82\) – they were being launched by somebody else! I can confirm that robots appear in ignition in one docker container when they are spawned in another.
content.html:
Setting the IGN_PARTITION on my two running containers to be different did not seem to fix the issue (I used IGN_PARTITION=subt$(date +%s%N) in the Dockerfile)

As a side note: if ignition is running in the docker container, I can interact with it from the host if I set the IGN_PARTITION=subt variable\

Also: this solves our other mystery of why we got robots even though robot names were not specified on the command line (see e.g. issue #82) – they were being launched by somebody else! I can confirm that robots appear in ignition in one docker container when they are spawned in another.

content.raw: Our temporary in-house work-around is to remove “--network host” from run.bash but hopefully the IGN\_PARTITION fix works better.
content.html: Our temporary in-house work-around is to remove “--network host” from run.bash but hopefully the IGN_PARTITION fix works better.

content.raw:
Ok, I’m fairly certain this _is_ related to the IGN\_PARTITION environment variable. Steps to fix/reproduce:

1. run two docker containers on the same subt image
2. in one container, edit virtual\_stix.ign to change the ROS\_MASTER\_URI port to 11312 \(also change the first roslaunch to include -p 11312\) - this ensures they do not share a ROS master
3. run `ign launch -v 4 virtual_stix.ign` in one image
4. run `ign launch -v 4 virtual_stix.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1` in the other

This will pop a robot into both simulations. If you change the IGN\_PARTITION environment variable in one of the docker containers, you don’t see this happen. Clock issues were \(I presume\) happening when the ros1\_ign\_bridge was getting connections from multiple gazebo instances.
content.html:
Ok, I’m fairly certain this is related to the IGN_PARTITION environment variable. Steps to fix/reproduce:

  1. run two docker containers on the same subt image
  2. in one container, edit virtual_stix.ign to change the ROS_MASTER_URI port to 11312 (also change the first roslaunch to include -p 11312) - this ensures they do not share a ROS master
  3. run ign launch -v 4 virtual_stix.ign in one image
  4. run ign launch -v 4 virtual_stix.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 in the other

This will pop a robot into both simulations. If you change the IGN_PARTITION environment variable in one of the docker containers, you don’t see this happen. Clock issues were (I presume) happening when the ros1_ign_bridge was getting connections from multiple gazebo instances.

content.raw: Also, if you leave the IGN_PARTITION empty then you shouldn't see cross talk.
content.html: Also, if you leave the IGN_PARTITION empty then you shouldn't see cross talk.

content.raw: Maybe IGN\_PARTITION empty should be the default in the Dockerfile?
content.html: Maybe IGN_PARTITION empty should be the default in the Dockerfile?

content.raw: See pull request #179
content.html: See pull request #179

content.raw: Unsetting IGN_PARTITION should do the trick.
content.html: Unsetting IGN_PARTITION should do the trick.
